title: Genomic Coverage from Whole Genome Bisulfite Sequencing Data
text:
Description
DNA sequencing is a common practice in biomedical research. The sequencing process requires collecting DNA from a sample (e.g., a tumor biopsy or a healthy tissue nearby), extracting the DNA from the cells, and then fragmenting the full length DNA strands into smaller chunks. These chunks are then placed on a “sequencer,” where the individual bases are read from the DNA fragments. The output from the sequencer is called a “read” and is then aligned back to a reference genome (the human reference genome is about three billion bases long) in order to find where the small fragment (usually around 100-150 bases in length) came from.
One possible analysis that can be done is to find the “coverage” across the entire genome. To do this, you count the total number of reads that cover each individual loci, or base, in the genome. One example of performing this analysis is as a part of a quality control pipeline within BISCUIT to verify a sequencing experiment consistently covered the entire genome. Currently, the pipeline uses bedtools to do this, but it is a slow process. One option for improving the speed of this process would be to use mosdepth, a tool specifically designed for finding coverages. However, it does not calculate the exact metrics needed in the BISCUIT quality control pipeline.
This project improves upon the existing bedtools implementation by calculating the needed metrics on the fly and utilizing parallelization during processing. The tool is written in C for plugging in to BISCUIT following its completion.


Deliverables

Artifacts

System request
Diagrams (use case, activity, etc.)

Documents

Project proposal
Software Requirements Specification
Software Requirements Specification (Final Version)
Midterm Presentation

Meeting Minutes

30 September 2024
07 October 2024
14 October 2024
23 October 2024
28 October 2024
04 November 2024

title: Overview
text:
Overview
This document servers as the software requirements specification for the GVSU CIS 641 full semester project. Both functional and non-functional requirements are described.


Abbreviation Definitions

SAM file: Sequence Alignment Map file
BAM file: Binary Alignment Map file
BED file: Browser Extensible Data file
CIGAR string: Compact Idiosyncratic Gapped Alignment Report string
Top GC: Top ten (10) percent of windows in the genome for GC content.
Bottom GC: Bottom ten (10) percent of windows in the genome for GC content.
MAPQ: Mapping quality score



Functional Requirements

Command Line Interface Requirements

The command line interface shall accept an optional integer for the number of CPU threads.
The command line interface shall accept an optional integer for the window step size.
The command line interface shall accept an optional string for a prefix to all output file names.
The command line interface shall accept an optional file path for the genomic windows with the top ten (10) percent of GC content.
The command line interface shall accept an optional file path for the genomic windows with the bottom ten (10) percent of GC content.
The command line interface shall accept a required file path for the CpG genomic locations.
The command line interface shall accept a required file path for the input alignment file.
The command line interface shall set a default value for the number of CPU threads when the corresponding command line option is not provided.
The command line interface shall set a default value for the window step size when the corresponding command line option is not provided.
The command line interface shall not prepend anything to the output file names when the prefix command line option is not provided.
The command line interface shall check the number of CPU threads are valid greater than zero (0).
The command line interface shall set the number of CPU threads to the default value when the given value is less than or equal to zero (0).
The command line interface shall check the window step size is greater than zero (0).
The command line interface shall set the window step size to the default value when the given value is less than or equal to zero (0).

File Input Requirements

The program shall read Sequence Alignment Map (SAM) files.
The program shall read Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files.
The program shall accept one SAM or BAM file as the alignment file input.
The program shall extract chromosome sizes from the input SAM or BAM files.
The program shall read Browser Extensible Data (BED) files.
The program shall require BED files to be block gzipped.

File Output Requirements

The program shall have two output file types: a coverage distribution file (referred to as “covdist”) and a coefficient of variation file (referred to as “cv”).
The cv file shall have a two line header.

The first line of the cv file shall say: “BISCUITqc Uniformity Table”.
The second line of the cv file shall say: “group mu sigma cv”.
The words on the second line of the cv file shall be separated by tab characters.

All lines after the two line header in the cv file shall be tab separated.
All lines after the two line header in the cv file shall contain (in the following order) a group name (see Functional Requirements 3.4.1-3.4.12 for group names), the mean coverage, the coverage standard deviation, and the coverage coefficient of variation.

The group name for coverage across bases covered by all applicable reads shall be “all_base”.
The group name for coverage across bases covered by reads with a mapping quality score (MAPQ) greater than or equal to forty (40) shall be “q40_base”.
The group name for coverage across CpGs covered by all applicable reads shall be “all_cpg”.
The group name for coverage across CpGs covered by reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) shall be “q40_cpg”.
The group name for coverage across bases covered by all applicable reads and fall in the top GC windows shall be “all_base_topgc” when a top GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across bases covered by reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the top GC windows shall be “q40_base_topgc” when a top GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across CpGs covered by all applicable reads and fall in the top GC windows shall be “all_cpg_topgc” when a top GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across CpGs covered by reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the top GC windows shall be “q40_cpg_topgc” when a top GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across bases covered by all applicable reads and fall in the bottom GC windows shall be “all_base_botgc” when a bottom GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across bases covered by reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the bottom GC windows shall be “q40_base_botgc” when a bottom GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across CpGs covered by all applicable reads and fall in the bottom GC windows shall be “all_cpg_botgc” when a bottom GC file is provided.
The group name for coverage across CpGs covered by reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the bottom GC windows shall be “q40_cpg_botgc” when a bottom GC file is provided.

There shall be one covdist file for each set of coverages found (listed in Functional Requirements 3.5.1-3.5.12).

One covdist file shall be for bases covered by all applicable reads and shall have the tag “All Bases”.
One covdist file shall be for bases covered by all applicable reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and shall have the tag “Q40 Bases”.
One covdist file shall be for CpGs covered by all applicable reads and shall have the tag “All CpGs”.
One covdist file shall be for CpGs covered by all applicable reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and shall have the tag “Q40 CpGs”.
One covdist file shall be for bases covered by all applicable reads and fall in the top GC windows and shall have the tag “All Top GC Bases” when a top GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for bases covered by all applicable reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the top GC windows and shall have the tag “Q40 Top GC Bases” when a top GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for CpGs covered by all applicable reads and fall in the top GC windows and shall have the tag “All Top GC CpGs” when a top GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for CpGs covered by all applicable reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the top GC windows and shall have the tag “Q40 Top GC CpGs” when a top GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for bases covered by all applicable reads and fall in the bottom GC windows and shall have the tag “All Bot GC Bases” when a bottom GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for bases covered by all applicable reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the bottom GC windows and shall have the tag “Q40 Bot GC Bases” when a bottom GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for CpGs covered by all applicable reads and fall in the bottom GC windows and shall have the tag “All Bot GC CpGs” when a bottom GC file is provided.
One covdist file shall be for CpGs covered by all applicable reads with MAPQ greater than or equal to forty (40) and fall in the bottom GC windows and shall have the tag “Q40 Bot GC CpGs” when a bottom GC file is provided.

Each covdist file shall have a two line header.

The first line of each covdist file shall say: “BISCUITqc Depth Distribution - TAG” where TAG is replaced by a tag unique to each covdist file (see Functional Requirements 3.5.1-3.5.12 for the tags).
The second line of each covdist file shall say: “depth count”.
The words on the second line of each covdist file shall be separated by tab characters.

All lines after the two line header in the covdist file shall be tab separated.
All lines after the two line header in the covdist file shall contain the coverage level in the first position of the line and the number of bases with that coverage level in the second position of the line.

Parallel Processing Requirements

The program shall use POSIX threads for multithreaded processing.
The program shall split the chromosome into equal sized bins.

The program shall allow the last bin to be less than the bin size if the chromosome cannot be broken up evenly.

A thread shall store its block identification number.
A thread shall store its bin start position.
A thread shall store its bin end position.
A thread shall store a bit array of positions in the bin that are covered by CpGs.
A thread shall store a bit array of positions in the bin that are covered by top GC windows.

The bit array shall be all zeroes (0s) if no top GC file is provided.

A thread shall store a bit array of positions in the bin that are covered by bottom GC windows.

The bit array shall be all zeroes (0s) if no bottom GC file is provided.


SAM/BAM File Processing Requirements

The program shall ignore unmapped reads.
The program shall ignore reads that are not primary alignments.
The program shall ignore reads that fail platform/vendor quality checks.
The program shall ignore reads that are PCR or optical duplicates.
The program shall ignore reads that are supplementary alignments.
The program shall extract the CIGAR string from a mapped read alignment.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is an alignment match.
The program shall not change the reference position if the CIGAR operation is an insertion.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a deletion.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a skipped region from the reference.
The program shall not change the reference position if the CIGAR operation is a soft clipped base.
The program shall not change the reference position if the CIGAR operation is a hard clipped base.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a sequence match.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a sequence mismatch.
The program shall count a base as covered if the CIGAR operation is an alignment match, a sequence match, or a sequence mismatch.
The program shall not count a base as covered if the CIGAR operation is an insertion, a deletion, a soft clipped base, a hard clipped base, or a skipped region from the reference.




Non-Functional Requirements

Operating Requirements

The program shall work on Linux systems.
The program shall work on macOS systems.
The program shall run from a terminal.
The program shall work through a command line interface.
The program shall work on x86 CPU architectures.
The program shall work on ARM CPU architectures.

Performance Requirements

The program shall read a genomic window from a block gzipped BED file in two (2) seconds or less.
The program shall process at least one thousand (1000) reads per second.
The program shall process at least one million (1,000,000) basepairs of data per second.
The program shall use eight (8) gigabytes or less of random access memory.
The program shall compile in fifteen (15) seconds or less.

Usability Requirements

The program shall use English comments.
The program shall provide a help message for the user.
The program shall provide error messages upon system failure.
The program shall have a companion website describing usage.
The program shall provide an example dataset.
The program shall provide a tutorial for users.

Availability Requirements

The program shall be available for no cost.
The program shall be available to the public.
The program shall be available on GitHub.
The program shall be available in pre-compiled binaries.
The program shall be available through bioconda.

Maintainability Requirements

The program shall use Git for version control.
The program shall use semantic versioning.
Issues shall be acknowledged within two (2) business days.
Pull requests shall be acknowledged within two (2) business days.
Minor issues (e.g., bugs) shall be resolved within five (5) business days.
Major issues (e.g., feature requests) shall be resolved within fifteen (15) business days.

title: Introduction
text:
Team name: Packing the Bits
Team members: Jacob Morrison

Introduction
DNA sequencing is a common practice in biomedical research. The sequencing process requires collecting DNA from a sample (e.g., a tumor biopsy or a healthy tissue nearby), extracting the DNA from the cells, and then fragmenting the full length DNA strands into smaller chunks. These chunks are then placed on a “sequencer,” where the individual bases are read from the DNA fragments. The output from the sequencer is called a “read” and is then aligned back to a reference genome (the human reference genome is about three billion bases long) in order to find where the small fragment (usually around 100-150 bases in length) came from.
One possible analysis that can be done is to find the “coverage” across the entire genome. To do this, you count the total number of reads that cover each individual loci, or base, in the genome. One example of performing this analysis is as a part of a quality control pipeline within BISCUIT (a project I maintain for work) to verify a sequencing experiment consistently covered the entire genome. Currently, the pipeline uses bedtools to do this, but it is a slow process. One option for improving the speed of this process would be to use mosdepth, a tool specifically designed for finding coverages. However, it does not calculate the exact metrics that I need.
I propose writing a small tool that improves upon the existing bedtools implementation and calculates the metrics I need on the fly. The tool will be written in C for plugging in to BISCUIT following the completion of class. It will also be multithreaded to improve the efficiency of the single-threaded bedtools option. Depending on the final state of the project, it may be sufficient to warrant an academic publication (either as a pre-print or a peer-reviewed application note).


Anticipated Technologies

OS: macOS or Linux
Editor: vim
Language: C
Third-Party Libraries:

htslib
POSIX threads
zlib




Method/Approach
Broadly, I plan to start off with doing as much analysis and design ahead of time as I can. This will include defining as many requirements at the outset of the project (although I anticipate having to revise these during the implementation stage). I plan to give myself the most time on the implementation stage, with an approximately equal amount of time for analysis, design, and implementation. Testing will have a shorter amount of dedicated time; however, I plan to write some of the tests during the implementation stage. For the sake of this project, most of my tests will focus on the output of the tool to ensure it returns the same values as before. I will include some unit tests on some of the smaller functionality, but these won’t be the focus of my tests.


Estimated Timeline



Task
Estimated Completion Date




Analysis
30 September 2024


Design
14 October 2024


Requirements
14 October 2024


Implementation
14 November 2024


Testing
31 November 2024


Wrapping Up
6 December 2024





Anticipated Problems
Potential problems include, but are not limited to:

Design

Creating class diagrams

Implementation

Handling reads that span adjacent regions handled by different threads
Merging regions of similar coverage that span adjacent regions
Handling regions of interest to calculate metrics for

Testing

Unit testing

title: Overview
text:
Overview
This document servers as the software requirements specification for the GVSU CIS 641 full semester project. Both functional and non-functional requirements are described.


Abbreviation Definitions

SAM file: Sequence Alignment Map file
BAM file: Binary Alignment Map file
BED file: Browser Extensible Data file
CIGAR string: Compact Idiosyncratic Gapped Alignment Report string



Functional Requirements

Command Line Interface Requirements

The command line interface shall accept an integer for the amount of CPU threads.
The command line interface shall accept a file path for the input.
The command line interface shall check the inputs are valid.
The command line interface shall accept a file path for the output.
The command line interface shall accept an optional file of regions of interest.
The command line interface shall accept an integer for chromosome bin width.

File Input Requirements

The program shall read Sequence Alignment Map (SAM) files.
The program shall read Binary Alignment Map (BAM) files.
The program shall read Browser Extensible Data (BED) files.
The program shall accept one SAM or BAM file as input.
The program shall extract chromosome sizes from the input SAM or BAM files.

File Output Requirements

The program shall output a BED-compliant file.
The output shall be sorted first by chromsome, then by start position, then by end position.
The output shall have a fourth (4th) column with the coverage value at that base.
The output shall merge consecutive bases with the same coverage
The output shall be tab-separated.

Parallel Processing Requirements

The program shall use POSIX threads for multithreaded processing.
The program shall split the chromosome into equal sized bins.

The program shall allow the last bin to be less than the bin size if the chromosome cannot be broken up evenly.

The program shall share an open read-only file handle of the input SAM or BAM file across threads.
A thread shall store its bin start position.
A thread shall store its bin end position.
A thread shall store its output as a string.

SAM/BAM File Processing Requirements

The program shall ignore unmapped reads.
The program shall ignore reads that are not primary alignments.
The program shall ignore reads that fail platform/vendor quality checks.
The program shall ignore reads that are PCR or optical duplicates.
The program shall ignore reads that are supplementary alignments.
The program shall extract the CIGAR string from a mapped read alignment.
The program shall increment one base along the read if the CIGAR operation is an alignment match.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is an alignment match.
The program shall increment one base along the read if the CIGAR operation is an insertion.
The program shall not change the reference position if the CIGAR operation is an insertion.
The program shall not change the read position if the CIGAR operation is a deletion.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a deletion.
The program shall not change the read position if the CIGAR operation is a skipped region from the reference.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a skipped region from the reference.
The program shall increment one base along the read if the CIGAR operation is a soft clipped base.
The program shall not change the reference position if the CIGAR operation is a soft clipped base.
The program shall not change the read position if the CIGAR operation is a hard clipped base.
The program shall not change the reference position if the CIGAR operation is a hard clipped base.
The program shall increment one base along the read if the CIGAR operation is a sequence match.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a sequence match.
The program shall increment one base along the read if the CIGAR operation is a sequence mismatch.
The program shall increment one base along the reference if the CIGAR operation is a sequence mismatch.
The program shall count as base as covered if the CIGAR operation is an alignment match, a sequence match, or a sequence mismatch.
The program shall not count as base as covered if the CIGAR operation is an insertion, a deletion, a soft clipped base, a hard clipped base, or a skipped region from the reference




Non-Functional Requirements

Operating Requirements

The program shall work on Linux systems.
The program shall work on macOS systems.
The program shall run from a terminal.
The program shall work through a command line interface.
The program shall work on x86 CPU architectures.
The program shall work on ARM CPU architectures.

Performance Requirements

The program shall read a region file in five (5) seconds.
The program shall process at least one thousand (1000) reads per second.
The program shall process at least one million (1,000,000) basepairs of data per second.
The program shall use eight (8) gigabytes or less of random access memory.
The program shall compile in fifteen (15) seconds or less.

Usability Requirements

The program shall use English comments.
The program shall provide a help message for the user.
The program shall provide error messages upon system failure.
The program shall having a companion website describing usage.
The program shall provide an example dataset.
The program shall provide a tutorial for users.

Availiability Requirements

The program shall be available for no cost.
The program shall be available to the public.
The program shall be available on GitHub.
The program shall be available in pre-compiled binaries.
The program shall be available through bioconda.

Maintainability Requirements

The program shall use Git for version control.
The program shall use semantic versioning.
Issues shall be acknowledged within two (2) business days.
Pull requests shall be acknowledged within two (2) business days.
Minor issues (e.g., bugs) shall be resolved within five (5) business days.
Major issues (e.g., feature requests) shall be resolved within fifteen (15) business days.

title: Request Creator
text:
Request Creator

Jacob Morrison



Project Sponsor
Dr. Erik Fredericks


Business Need
This project exists to improve the efficiency of quality control of DNA sequencing experiments by merging multiple steps of the process into a single executable.


Business Requirements

Merge coverage determination and statistical calculations
Use multithreading to improve efficiency
Integrate process within existing toolkit



Business Value
I expect this project will reduce the time it takes to run the full quality control script, thereby decreasing the time it takes to complete the initial analysis. Further, this reduction in time will benefit clinical users, who often work in environments with limited resources and tight timelines.


Special Issues or Constraints

Project will be as a standalone tool before being integrated into existing toolkit
Potential issue: Merging data from individual threads
Potential issue: Allowing user to process a subset of data
